author: Jane Byrne
title: Just Back: Candied walnuts and communism in Albania
text:
Albania Just Back: Candied walnuts and communism in Albania Jane Byrne wins £200 for her touching account of a meeting with an elderly lady who provides a link between old and modern-day Albania In Mangalem, the old city of Berat in Albania, residents remember living through communism Photo: AP By Jane Byrne Comments 
It could be a black and white photograph – grey limestone cobbles underfoot, on either side high whitewashed walls and ahead, framed in a dark doorway, Margarita, whose black dress and white hair continue the illusion. Only the brilliant sky and the vivid pink geraniums by the door indicate that this is no photograph. Deep in the heart of Mangalem, the old city of Berat in Albania , Margarita invites us in. 
• Is Albania Europe's best-kept secret? 
The room is cool and dark as I cross to look out the window. The houses tumble down to the river with its old and new bridges and bustling modern centre. The heat and city noise rise up but inside all is quiet and calm. Gradually my eyes become accustomed to the dim light. In the corners stand heavy pieces of furniture, no doubt inherited. Couches line the walls, leaving the centre of the room clear. 
I begin to distinguish images on the walls. Against a deep sea-green background are classical temples, boats, fishermen and islands picked out in grey, white and black. A frieze of fruits and leaves runs above and below. This mural runs around the room, portraying an ancient, peaceful landscape. Margarita explains that her house was occupied by Italians in 1942 and they painted the mural, but whether to while away the time, remind them of home or in gratitude for a comfortable billet she does not know. 
Candied walnuts are offered by the writer's Albanian companion (Photo: AP) 
We are invited to question Margarita. She answers at length. In her youth her family was well-to-do but lost property and status under communism. Now 72, she has her home and some orchards. She supplements her income by making and selling preserves. Having left the room, she returns with a tray of her wares – jars of plum and apricot jam plus a mysterious dark jar in which black fruits can be seen. It turns out to be candied walnuts. 
Margarita explains the laborious process – the selection of nuts, the first stage of cooking and how each walnut is pricked with a needle to test if it is cooked. She shows us the sharp peeling knife and the tips of her fingers stained black from handling the nuts. The final stage is preparing the syrup and the actual candying process. Her passion and pride in her work shines through. 
Soon it is time to leave and continue on our journey through Albania. 
I summon up my few words of Albanian. “Thank you,” I say, “thank you, Margarita, and goodbye.” The response is a warm hug and a kiss. 
Now it seems like a dream, Margarita in her cool sea-green room, in the heart of the old town candying walnuts as generations have done before while modern life rushes on below. Enter the next round
